title: Recall & Confidence
summary: Recharge crate comfort while teaching puppies that coming when called is the best party.

lessons.title: Ping-Pong Recall
lessons.objective: Build lightning-fast runs between two people.
steps: Person A kneels, says the puppy's name once, then the recall cue here.
Celebrate with five rapid treats when the puppy arrives.
Person B calls as soon as the puppy is eating the last treat, rewarding on arrival.
Add gentle distractions like clapping or sitting farther apart after success.
supportGuidelines: Coach families to keep cues upbeat—no angry tone, even if the puppy detours.
Encourage practicing on leash outside before trying off-leash spaces.
Track success rate; aim for 90% indoors before moving outdoors.
lessons.safetyNotes: Avoid slick floors that could cause sliding when the puppy sprints.

lessons.title: Trade Game
lessons.objective: Prevent resource guarding by teaching puppies to swap calmly.
steps: Give the puppy a low-value chew to hold.
Present a treat to their nose, say trade, and mark when they release the chew.
Return the original chew or upgrade to the higher-value item.
Repeat with random household objects (tug rope, sock) once they understand the game.
supportGuidelines: Remind humans to keep hands relaxed—no yanking objects away.
Encourage pairing this with polite drop cues later in the program.
Suggest journaling items the puppy guards so you can desensitize gradually.
lessons.safetyNotes: If the puppy stiffens or growls, pause the session and refer to a trainer.

lessons.title: Crate Comfort Boost
lessons.objective: Extend crate relaxation with layered rewards and calm exits.
steps: Cue kennel up and feed a treat just for entering.
Scatter kibble on a snuffle mat placed inside and close the door for one minute.
Return, drop three treats between the front paws, and quietly open the door.
Release only when the puppy offers eye contact, reinforcing that calm earns freedom.
supportGuidelines: Coach guardians to alternate crate location (bedroom vs. living room) to generalize.
Encourage pairing background music or white noise for puppies sensitive to sounds.
Share the door-islands technique—open a crack, reward, close, reopen wider—to prevent dashing.
lessons.safetyNotes: Ensure the puppy fully empties bladder before longer crate sessions.
